intro: Ophrys holosericea subsp. heterochila, commonly known as the heterochila bee orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species native to southern Europe. It is characterized by its unique floral morphology, featuring a lip that mimics the appearance of a female bee, which plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. The plant typically grows in calcareous soils and is often found in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and heaths. Its flowers are usually pale yellow to brownish in color, with intricate patterns that aid in attracting male bees for pollination. Due to habitat loss and fragmentation, this subspecies is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
